reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a lot of fun, although it is very limited and kind of overpriced for what it is at the moment. You'll pretty much manage to do everything there is within the game within the first couple of minutes.

Beyond that, it's fun to compete with friends.

WEAPONS
The weapons are kind of cool, but I wish I had more choice. You just have a pistol at the moment, but it has different firing types.

Single Shot: This is just your standard pistol, but you have a laser sight (In fact, it's currently the only one with a laser sight).

Triple Shot: You no longer have the laser sight, but you do have 3 shots fired in rapid succession when you pull the trigger. In order to fire again, you'll need to release and pull the trigger again.

Rapid Fire: All you need to do is hold the trigger to fire an endless supply of shots. The only problem is that the longer you hold the trigger, the slower the rate of fire.

Charge Shot: Hold down the trigger to charge it up, and released it to do a shot that will pretty much always destroy your target. The problem is, you have to be accurate to make use of it. Your sight will turn green when you're about to make a kill shot, so looking down the sights is pretty handy.

Laser: Fire a low powered laser from your gun. When you hit your target, they'll usually be stunned and start to fall. After a constant stream of shots, they'll blow up, but it's the slowest way of destroying the drones. HOWEVER! You if you equip a laser in both hands and cross the beams, you form a very powerful laser beam. This does massive damage, but of course, limits you to one direction of attack, and no defense.

DEFENSE
You start the match with 3 lives. So that's 3 shots and you're out! Even rapid fire from behind will end your match pretty quickly, but the game slows down when you're close to an enemy laser. It creates this pretty amazing Matrix feeling. I'm not sure if you gain lives after X number of waves, but I have a feeling that's the case. Usually I'm too busy fighting to count how many lives I have left.

Reach to your back and your gun is replaced with a shield. This can reflect shots back, and with a bit of luck, can actually reflect them back to your attacker. On top of this, pull the trigger to charge up and release a powerful shock wave. This can not only force your attackers back, but can also deflect shots.

LEVELS
There's currently just the one level... it's pretty nice to look around, and you'll mainly be attacked from the front and sides, but there's no variety.

ENEMIES
Beyond colours, I'm not sure what else there is. I understand there'll be boss fights soon, but at the moment you'll just be dealing with floating sphere drones. The look cool, and sound cool... but essentially repetitive.

MUSIC AND SOUND
This is subjective, but I get a lot of excitement from it. Fast paced drum and bass, and a great beat makes you feel pretty powerful and unstoppable... that is until you hear a drone charge up and shoot you in the back.

The guns sound awesome, and suitable. Nothing seems out of place or underpowered.

CONCLUSION
It has the potential to be a great game. At the moment it's fun and easy to drop in and out of, but don't expect too much at this time.

Hopefully we'll have a greater selection of weapons in the future (shotgun, please!), and a story mode would be pretty cool. It has a nice level of polish, and I look forward to seeing what we get in the future.

Yes, I'd recommend, even at this current level.

This game is the purest expression of Pew Pew I have ever experienced.

Update: So, I've played about 12 hours on this, which I feel is 'just about getting started' level. Let's face it, this game doesn't change. The scenery is the same, the droids are the same... the waves are (just about) the same. So this game should be pretty boring, really.

Except it's not. Because this game is about changing you. Changing you from the useless lump of putty you were into a ruthless droid destroying space pirate.

And it works. No more do I hide behind a shield whilst firing aimlessly into the air, hitting nothing. No more do I stand there, like a potato, letting the droids destroy me.

Now my ears listen out for their warm up noises. I know the bullet is coming, and I know where it's coming from. I dodge it without even bothering to look. I'm too busy. I aim at a droid, and I pull the triggers. Boom. I aim at the next one, pull the triggers... boom. One after another they fall. I don't miss, even as I duck and weave and dodge my way around the platform.

Then I start missing. There's too many of them. They're coming from all over now, and I've lost my cool. One hits me, then another... and then it's too late.

I put down the guns, admitting defeat. My training is far from over.

Strongly recommend for anyone with a Vive!

OK, I realize this game is early access, but I have to review it how it stands today, not on hopes of the future (Whatever they might be... The dev sure hasn't shown anything off that I'm aware of...) If it gets better, I'll revisit the review.

As it stands, this game is a monumental rip-off at $15, for the actual content you get. It's the minimum of effort in what a game could be, a tech demo that could be replicated in a week by one person. For 2 to 5 bucks, it might be OK, but when I can buy Jeeboman, which is nearly identical in play style, but is an actual game with progression, checkpoints, variety, balance, and gobs more fun than this yet only costs 10 bucks, why would I bother?

The weapons are unbalanced to the point of being useless. You'd think the single shot would be more powerful that a shot from the machinegun... but it isn't. So why the heck would I choose single shot, then, when machine gun is far more effective? the same goes for the 3-shot burst mode. Again, no more powerful, why would I use it? Because I'm stupid? The powerup shot that must be charged by holding the trigger is even more of a joke. It's just as hard to hit anything with it, and yet it takes multiple seconds to load each shot. If you want to die quickly, choose this. Ultimately, that leaves the laser beam and the machinegun... but it's easier to hit with the instant laser beam, so again, why would you use machinegun when there is a better option?

And to stress again, as it stands on the day I write this, there is NOTHING TO THIS GAME. Die, and you start all the way over with the incredibly boring first waves again, and again, and again. There is one enemy with texture alterations making three of them. There is one gun model that doesn't change based on type of firepower. The shield doesn't work right in the heat of combat, either sticking on or not coming up when you try to deploy it, costing you time, or more likely, your game for your effort of using it.

I remember seeing the demo of this game months and months ago and thinking it looked cool... and now when the Vive launches, the release version is that exact same demo, no changes. The developer has done NOTHING to the game in months and months, and calls it early access. I'd like to believe they'll continue, especially based on the faith Valve seemed to put in them as a featured developer, but I have to judge based on their output right now, and right now it's lazy, simplistic, and above all, boring. Avoid. Holopoint and Jeeboman are far better, and cost less.

Early Access Review

======================================
(First Impressions) - Space Pirate Trainer
======================================

Video Impression - https://youtu.be/EznjB8VkjCE

**Gameplay/My Experience**

I start off in a large hanger bay overlooking a large planets terrain covered with lights and glowing cityscapes. In my hands are two large pistol shaped weapons which will serve as my means to destroying robot hordes. Each weapon is able to cycle through different firing modes using the touch pads  such as single shot, burst fire, stream or charged shots. In front of me is a large holographic board that displays information such as high scores and other game information.

I start things off by shooting the lets rock" logo on the holographic menu
date: everything clears  away and im left standing in the bay alone and vulnerable. I take a quick look around before things start and notice a large spaceship behind me which I can only assume belongs to me
recommended: everything about this place feels exactly how you think it should in terms of future space ports. Floating billboards
hoursPlayed: huge sky full of beautiful stars it really sucks you in on the immersion factor.\n\nI am suddenly greeted by a small orb type robot that flys randomly around in flanking maneuvers but doesn't seem interested in shooting me just yet. I decide not to wait around to see him shoot
voteText: I take aim and fire. A solid stream of orange electrified energy spews from both guns into the star filled sky causing a direct hit on the robot and a fiery explosion.\n\nIt feels good
helpfulPercent: the explosion was awesome and i'm feeling pretty confident with my new guns
votesHelpful: bring on wave 2. This time I get a few more bots
votesTotal: I discover that raising my arm over my head causes me to pull out a clear riot shield that is able to deflect incoming enemy fire. The robots fly around me trying to surround and flank. I hear a beeping sound as one of the eyes of the robots lights up and fires. As the lasers approach me time slows down and i'm able to effectively move out of the way or block them with my shield.  After a dance around my space I am able to block and shoot down all the remaining bots.\n\nA few waves later i'm now around 9 or 10 things are getting very tense as the robots are getting smarter and more versatile. They fly under the platform i'm standing on to hide from view then pop up firing when i'm busy with others. I dash
votesFunny: jump crouch and do something close to a matrix dodge but bad enough that Morpheus would facepalm. Finally the bots are able to form an effective circle and all fire at once
commentsCount:
I desperately attempt to dodge the incoming attacks but am defeated by rounds to the chest and back.

==================================================

** Graphics/Audio **

Everything in this game is very top notch in the graphics department the detailed flashes from explosions and the clean cut edges of outgoing and incoming lasers just look fantastic.
The environment is very well detailed and gives you a true feeling of standing on a platform in space. The lighting on the billboards and animations of the guns all come together perfectly for a stunning combo of arcade like action.

The audio is also very well done
column16: The heavy sci fi electro beats put you in an almost dancing like state while you shoot
column17:
i found myself almost shooting robots to the beat of the music after awhile. That combined with the high quality sound effects of laser fire and robot explosion really put you in the mood for this title.

==================================================

**VR/Comfort**

Very smooth experience and very immersive

Space Pirate Trainer is the current go-to title for a  wave-based bullet hell.  Dodge incoming weapons-fire from free flying target drones while trying to dish out your own style of hurt using a multi-mode pistol or a reflective vortex shield in any/either/both hand. Difficulty ramps up the longer you survive.

Pros:
+Aiming so good I shot a drone behind my back without even looking.
+Great hitboxes.
+Good sound effects.
+Pleasing visuals.
+Difficulty ramps up and provides a real challenge.
+Online leader boards.
+The different pistol modes open a large amount of play styles. For instance, since my off hand has weaker aim I use the slower pistol with a laser sight to help aim and main hand an incredibly powerful auto-pistol.

Cons:
-Lack of content. Only one map and two weapons currently. Expect more to be added as development continues.
-No online play. Another title will eventually come out that does this in online co-op. Space Pirates dev's say online co-op is an eventual possibility."

This is one of the better Vive games. Everything about it is solid: The UI, visuals, mechanics, options, and gameplay.
Since it's in early access, I'll mention some improvements that the game could really use.

Different types of enemies, and even bosses, would make it MUCH more interesting. There are currently only 2 kinds of enemies, distinguishable by their colors. There could be a boss on one level that, when you deal enough damage to it's main body, it splits up into smaller drones or something.

A way to lock-in your gun and shield-config would be helpful. I've found that I accidentally switch to a gun I don't want, or accidentally bring up a shield in my right hand.

Powerups would be nice, and make people want to spend more time in the game.

It might be a stretch, but multiplayer would be so so cool. Battling other players would be very fun.

Differnet environments would be welcome. Right now, there is only one.

During gameplay, your crashed ship is parked behind you. It would take a lot of time to implement, but if the player could interact with the ship in some way, it would make gameplay feel more varied. For example, the player could gain a resource after every wave (like 'scrap metal'), and when the player has enough 'scrap metal', they can repair one of the ship's turrets. This turret could then fire at enemies for the next round (or time limit), giving the player an edge.

--------------------------------------------
Those are just some improvements that I think could be made. I still definitley reccomend this game! It's fair for the price, and very polished.

REVERSAL GAMER REVIEWS:

OVERALL SCORE: 9/10
While simple in principle, this is lot of fun for the whole family and shows the immersion capability of the HTC Vive.
Be prepaired to use your full room-scale space as you duck/dodge/weave from incumming drones and projectiles.
This is a must have for any early adobter of the HTC Vive.

GRAPHICS: 8/10
- In Game Graphics Options: Yes [GOOD & BETTER]
- Environment: Nice visuals, starships moving around in the background and a scense of a wide open space.
- Textures: Decent but nothing to write home about.
- AntiAliasing: Decent on BETTER preset.
- Performance: Nothing to demanding here and thus runs very smooth on AMD FuryX.

CONTROLLS: 10/10
- Fluid intuitive movement
- Down sight aiming
- Reach around your back to grab a handy shield to deflect incomming fire. Brilliant
- Customise shooting pitch

GAMEPLAY:
- Wave based gameplay that scales in difficulty as you progress. Once you reach Level 5 drones become more active and perform group attacks. This is where the fun hits overdrive and you'll panic/laugh with joy.
- Matrix style slow-motion when incomming fire approaches.
- Local and Public leaderboards to encorage that competitive spirit.
- Various firing modes available to mix it up and challange your sharp shooter skills.
